text: line; sitting on a raft in water, which is secretly fastened by a rope to a rock ; such magical performance in water as is usually done at night by bands of magicians, using the sack of abdomen or womb of water animals to hide the head and the nose, and applying to the nose the oil, prepared from the entrails of red spotted deer and the serum of the flesh of the crab, crocodile, porpoise and otter ; holding conversation, as though with women of Varupa (the god of water), or of Naga (the snake-god), when they are performing magical tricks in water ; and sending out volumes of smoke from the mouth on occasions of anger.' Astrologers, soothsayers, horologists, story tellers (Pauranika), as well as those who read the forebodings of every moment, together with spies and their disciples, inclusive of those who have witnessed the wonderful performances of the conqueror, should give wide publicity to the power of the king to associate with gods throughout his territory. Likewise in foreign countries, they should spread the news of gods appearing before the conqueror and of his having received from heaven weapons and treasure. Those who are well versed in horary and astrology and the science of omens should proclaim abroad that the conqueror is a successful expert in explaining the indications of dreams and in understanding the language of beasts and birds. They should not only attribute the contrary to his enemy, but also show to the enemy’s people the shower of firebrand (ulka) with the noise of drums (from the sky) on the day of the birth-star of the enemy. The conqueror’s chief messengers, pretending to be friendly towards the enemy, should highly speak of the conqueror’s respectful treatment of visitors, of the strength of his army, and of the likelihood of impending destruction of his enemy’s men. They should also make it known to the enemy that, under their master, both ministers and soldiers are equally safe and happy, and that their master treats his servants with parental care in their weal or woe. By these and other means they should win over the enemy’s men as pointed out above, and as we are going to treat of them again at length : They should characterise the enemy as an ordinary donkey towards skilful persons; as the branch of lakucha (Artocarpus Lacucha) broken to the officers of his array ; as a goat on the shore to anxious persons; as a downpour of lightnings to those who are treated with contempt; as a reed, a barren tree, or an iron ball, or as false clouds to those who are disappointed ; as the ornaments of an ugly woman to those who are disappointed in spite of their worshipful service; as a tiger’s skin, or as a trap of death to his favourites ; and as eating a piece of the wood of pilu (Careva-Arborea), or as churning the milk of a she-camel or a she-donkey (for butter) to those who are rendering to him valuable help. When the people of the enemy are convinced of this, they may be sent to the conqueror to receive wealth and honour. Those of the enemy who are in need of money and food should be supplied with an abundance of those things. Those who do not like to receive such things may be presented with ornaments for their wives and children. When the people of the enemy are suffering from famine and the oppression of thieves and wild tribes, the conqueror’s spies should sow the seeds of dissension among them, saying: Let us request the king for favour, and, go elsewhere if not favoured. When they agree to such proposals, they should be supplied with money, grains, and other necessary help: thus, much can be done by sowing the seeds of dissension.

section: Book XIII, Chapter II, Strategic Means to Capture a Fortress: Enticement of Kings by Secret Contrivances
text: An ascetic, with shaved head or braided hair and living in the cave of a mountain, may pretend to be four hundred years old, and, followed by a number of disciples with braided hair, halt in the vicinity of the capital city of the enemy. The disciples of the ascetic may make presentations of roots and fruits to the king and his ministers and invite them to pay a visit to the venerable ascetic. On the arrival of the king on the spot, the ascetic may acquaint him with the history of ancient kings and their states, and tell him . Every time when I complete the course of a hundred years, I enter into the fire and come out of it as a fresh youth (bala). Now, here in your presence, I am going to enter into the fire for the fourth time. It is highly necessary that you may be pleased to honour me with your presence at the time. Please request three boons.” When the king agrees to do so, he may be requested to come and remain at the spot with his wives and children for seven nights to witness the sacrificial performance. When he does so, he may be caught hold of. An ascetic, with shaved head or braided hair, and followed by a number of disciples with shaved heads or braided hair, and pretending to be aware of whatever is contained in the interior of the earth may put in the interior of an ant-hill either a bamboo stick wound round with a piece of cloth drenched in blood and painted with gold dust, or a hollow golden tube into which a snake can enter aud remain. One of the disciples may tell the king: “ This ascetic can discover blooming treasure trove.99 When he asks the ascetic (as to the veracity of the statement), the latter should acknowledge it, and produce a confirmatory evidence (by pulling out the bamboo stick); or having kept some more gold in the interior of the ant-hill, the ascetic may tell the king : “ This treasure trove is guarded by a snake and can possibly be taken out by performing necessary sacrifice. When the king agrees to do so, he may be requested to come aud remain.(as before). When an ascetic, pretending to be able to find out hidden treasure trove, is seated with his body burning with magical fire at night in a lonely place, disciples may bring the king to see him and inform the king that the ascetic can find out treasure trove. While engaged in performing some work at the request of the king, the latter may be requested to come and remain at the spot for seven nights.(as before). An accomplished ascetic may beguile a king by his knowledge of the science of magic known as jambhaka, and request him to come and remain.(as before). An accomplished ascetic, pretending to have secured the favour of the powerful guardian deity of the country, may often beguile the king’s chief ministers with his wonderful performance and gradually impose upon the king. Any person, disguised as an ascetic aud living under a bat or in the interior of an idol entered into through a tunnel or an underground chamber, may be said by his disciples to be Varuna, the god of water, or of the king of snakes, and shown to the king. While going to accomplish whatever the king may desire, the latter may be requested to come aud remain.(as before). An accomplished ascetic, halting in the vicinity of the capital city, may invite the king to witness the person (of his enemy). When he comes to witness the invocation of his enemy’s life in the image to be destroyed, he may be murdered in an unguarded place. Spies, under the guise of merchants come to sell horses, may invite the king to examine and purchase any of the animals. While attentively examining the horses, he may be murdered in the tumult or trampled down by horses. Getting into an altar at night in the vicinity of the capital city of the enemy and blowing through tubes or hollow reeds the fire contained in a few pots, some fiery spies may shout aloud : “ We are going to eat the flesh of the king or of his ministers ; let the worship of the gods go on.” Spies, under the guise of soothsayers and horologists, may spread the news abroad. Spies, disguised as Nagas (snake-gods) and with their body besmeared with burning oil (tejanataila), may stand in the centre of a sacred pool of water or of a lake at night, and sharpening their iron swords or spikes, may shout aloud as before. Spies, wearing coats formed of the skins of bears and sending out volumes of smoke from their mouth, may pretend to be demons, and after circumambulating the city thrice from right to left, may shout aloud as before at a place full of the horrid noise of antelopes and jackals ; or spies may set fire to an altar or an image of a god covered with a layer of mica besmeared with burning oil at night, and shout aloud as before. Others may spread this news abroad ; or they may cause (by some contrivance or other) blood to flow out in floods from revered images of gods. Others may point to the flow of blood and say that it is an indication of defeat to the enemy. On the night of full or new moon days or in the vicinity of a cremation ground they may point to a Chaitya tree with a human corpse, the upper part of which is eaten away. One, disguised as a demon, may call from the tree for the offering of a human victim. If a man boldly comes out to witness this, others may beat him to death with iron rods and make the people believe that he was killed by demons. Spies and other witnesses may inform the king of this wonder. Then spies, disguised as soothsayers and astrologers, may prescribe auspicious and expiatory rites to avert the evil consequences which would otherwise overtake the king and his country. When the king agrees to the proposal, he may be asked to perform in person special sacrifices and offerings with special mantras every night for seven days. Then (while doing this, he may be slain) as before. In order to delude other kings, the conqueror may himself undertake the performance of expiatory rites to avert such evil consequences as the above, and thus set an example to others. In view of averting the evil consequences of unnatural occurrences, he (the conqueror) may collect money (from his subjects). When the enemy is fond of elephants, spies may delude him with the sight of a beautiful elephant reared by the officer in charge of elephant forests. When he desires to capture the elephant, he may be taken to a remote desolate part of the forest, and killed or carried off as a prisoner. This explains the fate of kings addicted to hunting. When the enemy is fond of wealth or women, he may be beguiled at the sight of rich and beautiful widows brought before him with a plaint for the recovery of a deposit kept by them in the custody of one of their kinsmen ; and when he comes to meet with a woman at night as arranged, hidden spies may kill him with weapons or poison. When the enemy is in the habit of paying frequent visits to ascetics, altars, sacred pillars (stupa), and images of gods, spies hidden in underground chambers or in subterranean passages, or inside the walls, may strike him down.

section: Book XIV, Secret Means, Chapter I: Means to Injure an Enemy
text: In order to protect the institution of the four castes, such measures as are treated of in secret science shall be applied against the wicked. Through the instrumentality of such men or women of Mlechchha class as can put on disguises appropriate to different countries, arts, or professions, or as can put on the appearance of a hump-backed, dwarfish, or short-sized person, or of a dumb, deaf, idiot, or blind person, kalakfita and other manifold poisons should be administered in the diet and other physical enjoyments of the wicked. Spies lying in wait or living as inmates (in the same house) may make use of weapons on occasions of royal sports or musical and other entertainments. Spies, under the disguise of night-walkers (riitrichari) or of firekeepers (agni-jivi) may set fire (to the houses of the wicked). section: Chapter III The Application of Medicines and Mantras
text:
Having pulled out both the right and the left eye-balls of a cat, camel, wolf, boar, porcupine, vagnli (!), naptr (?), crow and owl, or of any one, two, or three, or many of such animals as roam at nights, one should reduce them to two kinds of powder. Whosoever anoints his own right eye with the powder of the left eyeball and his left eye with the powder of the right eyeball can clearly see things even in pitch dark at night.
One is the eye of a boar; another is that of a kbudyulu [firefly?], or a crow, or a hamsa bird. Having anointed one's own eyes with the above, one can clearly see things at night.
Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the day of the star Pushya, catch hold of the skull of a man who has been killed with a weapon or put to the gallows. Having filled the skull with soil and barley seeds, one should irrigate them with the milk of goats and sheep. Putting on the garland formed of the sprouts of the above barley crop, one can walk invisible to others.
Having fasted for three nights and having afterwards pulled out on the day of the star of Pushya both the right and the left of a dog, an owl, and a vaguli (!), one should reduce them to two kinds of powder. Then, having anointed one's own eyes with this ointment as usual, one can walk invisible to others.
Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the day of the star of Pushya, prepare a round-headed pin (sulaka) from the branch of purushaghiti (punnaga tree). Then having filled with ointment (anjana) the skull of any of the animals which roam at nights, and having inserted that skull in the organ of procreation of a dead woman, one should burn it. Having taken it out on the day of the star of Pushya and having anointed one's own eyes with that ointment, one can walk invisible to others.
Whenever one may happen to see the corpse burnt or just being burnt of a Brahman who kept perpetual fire (while alive), there one should fast for three nights; and having on the day of the star of Pushya formed a sack from the garment of the corpse of a man who is dead from natural causes, and having filled the sack with the ashes of the Brahman's corpse, one may put the sack on one's back, and walk invisible to others.
The slough of a snake filled with the powder of the bones and marrow or fat of the cow sacrificed during the funeral rites of a Brahman, can, when put on the back of cattle, render them invisible.
The slough of prachalika bird (?) filled with the ashes of the corpse of a man dead from snake-bite, can render beasts (mrga) invisible.
The slough of a snake (ahi) filled with the powder of the bone or the knee-joint mixed with dust of the tail and dung (prasruta) of an owl and… can render birds invisible.
Such are the eight kinds of the contrivances causing invisibility.

section: Chapter III The Application of Medicines and Mantras (continued)
text:
I bow to Bagirooha ; to Sambara acquainted with a hundred kinds of magic ; to Hanumarupoku, Naraka, Nilambha, and Kumbha, … and Nagida (I bow to Shaivagilava) ; with the permission of these I cause deep slumber to thee.
Just as the snakes known as Angara (boa-constrictor) fall into deep slumber, so may the rogues of the army who are very anxious to keep separate fires over the villages with their thousands of dogs (shvanakaja) and hundreds of ruddy geese, and donkeys, fall into deep slumber, and enter this house, and may the dogs be quiet.
Having bowed to Manu, and having gathered the roguish dogs (sunakapralayaka) and having also bowed to those gods who are in heaven, and to Brahmans among mankind ; to these who are well versed in their Vedic studies, those who have attained to Kailasa (mountain of god Shiva) by observing penance, and to all prophets, I do cause deep slumber to thee.
The fan (chinna) comes out; may all combinations retire. Oblation to Manu, O Aditi and Diti.
The application of the above mantra is as follows: Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month, the day being aligned to the star Pushya, purchase from a low-caste woman (tripashki) vilkinvukkhara (finger nails?). Having kept them in a basket (kavadalika), one should bury them apart in cremation grounds. Having unearthed them on the next fourteenth day, one should reduce them to a paste with kundri (aloe?) and prepare small pills out of the paste. Wherever one of the pills is thrown, chanting the above mantra, then the whole animal life falls into deep slumber.
Following the same procedure, one should separately bury in cremation grounds three white and three black dart-like hairs (shalyaka) of a porcupine. When, having on the next fourteenth day taken them out, one throws them together with the ashes of a burnt corpse, dictating the above mantra, the whole animal life in that place falls into deep slumber.
I bow to the goddess Shovarrapuspha and to Brahmans, to the god Brahman, and to Kushadhvaja; I bow to all serpents and gandharvas; I bow to all ascetics.
May all Brahmans and Kshatriyas come under my power; may all Vaisyas and Sudras be at my beck and call. Oblation to thee, O Aditi, Kimita, Vajrini, Tarayoga, Puluka, Avayuhva, Vishakha, and Marakataka, oblation to thee.

section: Maintaining Royal Authority and Warfare
text: To maintain authority and the right over subjects, a king must be knowledgeable in the science of politics. A king's vigilance is compared to a drawn sword, sharp and lucid. He must be wary of nuclear ability and assert his right to counter.  He must be impartial, even towards an enemy. The elements of a conquered territory must be understood. What to take away for life. A king must be wary of his own people as well as his enemies. Good relations must be maintained between king and his people. He must punish traitors.  A king's men should not be idle, dejected, and powerless. With money and army, one can be successful in intrigue. Power is multiplied by men. Those well-versed in intrigue will prevail. A king needs to be knowledgeable about attacks in a cabin or a forest, from behind an elevation, or on his flanks.  He must know how to break a combination of attacks.  How such combinations are respected. With what kind of troops to combine. What forces are to be relegated.  Which troops are enjoyable in ease or many ways. The conduct of friendly, neutral, and serviceable forces. How to distinguish forces that are to be quartered or apart.  Obtainment of forces by secret contrivances. Kautilya's political views.

section: Part 1: Mandala Theory in Ancient and Modern Contexts
text: Competition between kingdoms triggers a ruler to reinforce their mandala position within an unstable geopolitical circle.  While Ayudhya functioned as a state, its Mandala encompassed smaller kingdoms acting as "little kings" within loosely integrated territories. The concept of 'mandala' as a traditional Southeast Asian knowledge system, influencing 'international relations,' originates from ancient Indian political discourse, complemented by Chinese thought.  Ancient Cāṇakya theory, while adaptable to modern states, has seen varied interpretations. This study's importance lies in its unique focus on the Mandala theory's relevance to Indonesian geopolitics and geostrategy.

section: Part 2: Arthaśāstra and its Core Principles
text: The Mandala Theory is a key doctrine within the Arthaśāstra, an ancient treatise on statecraft by Cāṇakya (Kautilya) during the Mauryan Empire.  Arthaśāstra encompasses both 'science of wealth' and 'political science/science of government.'  Kautilya, prime minister to King Chandragupta, compiled this comprehensive guide around 300 BC, addressing governance, foreign policy, and national goal achievement, including territorial expansion. Written within an anarchic international system, Arthaśāstra promotes realism, self-help, and power accumulation for state survival, emphasizing conquest or be conquered.  The treatise comprises three parts: country administration (internal organization), law and justice (legal codes and enforcement), and foreign policy (territorial acquisition). These align with the state's goals: wealth/welfare, justice, and growth.  Compiled from ancient Hindu political texts, traditions, and experience, Arthaśāstra contains 32 parts, 15 books, 180 sections, and 6000 verses.

meta.usage_tags: ancient Indian text, political science, realism, power dynamics

section: Part 3:  Arthaśāstra's Structure and Mandala Theory's Place
text: The first book of Arthaśāstra discusses the king's training, ministerial appointments, security, and state safety. The second addresses executive officials' duties. The seventh outlines the Mandala (circle of state) theory and six-fold foreign policy (Ṣāḍguṇya) for achieving national welfare. The eleventh addresses defense against oligarchies. The thirteenth covers conquering fortified capitals through diplomacy or force, and governing conquered territories. The fourteenth explores secret methods, including medicine and occult practices, to destroy enemies. The fifteenth details 32 methods for managing subjects and scientific tools. Arthaśāstra provides guidance for building and preserving state power within competitive environments, addressing political subversion and social instability. The eighth book discusses internal and external threats (vyasana), such as rebellions, famines, corruption, natural disasters, enemy invasions, and foreign agent infiltration. The most significant external threat originates from neighboring countries, forming the basis of the Mandala theory.

section: Part 4: Mandala Theory - Geopolitical Constellation and its Application
text: Mandala theory maps the geopolitical landscape, categorizing twelve state types: vijigīṣu (conqueror), ari (enemy), mitra (ally), arimitra (enemy's ally), mitramitra (ally's friend), arimitramitra (ally of enemy's friend), parsnigraha (rear enemy), akranda (rear ally), parsnigrahasara (ally of rear enemy), akrandasara (ally of rear ally), madhyama (middle king/power), and udasina (neutral/major power). This symbolic constellation, with potential overlaps between kingdoms, isn't geographically fixed. Neighboring countries can be hostile, friendly, or subordinate. Cāṇakya acknowledged that not all neighbors are enemies, categorizing them as aribhavin (hostile), mitrabhavin (friendly), or bhrytyabhavin (brotherly), based on behavior, shared goals, interests, and alliances. Mandala theory guides foreign policy during the Maurya dynasty, determining cooperation or conquest, followed by ṣāḍguṇya (six-fold foreign policy) and catur upaya (four strategies: sama, dama, bedha, danda).  This constellation spread with Southeast Asian kingdoms. The Ayudhya kingdom, for example, utilized the mandala pattern for defense, achieving significant influence. Kautilya's Mandala concept was later adopted to describe pre-colonial Southeast Asian political formations, which prioritized the center over boundaries and accommodated tributary polities without administrative integration. Mandala theory embodies the plan for world conquest, prioritizing strength and power.

section: Kautilya's Tripartite Power and Mandala Theory
text: Kautilya identified three powers: Mantrashakti (knowledge/counsel), Prabhu Shakti (might/treasury and army), and Utsaha shakti (energy/bravery).  He linked these to a threefold concept of success, emphasizing the king's imperative to conquer or be conquered.  Kautilya's focus was victory, world conquest, and the establishment of a unified empire, particularly encompassing the Indian territories between the Himalayas and the sea.  This theory, with its focus on interstate relations and geopolitical analysis, can be considered a theory of geopolitics. The Mandala geopolitical theory from Kautilya's Arthashastra found application in Classical Southeast Asia, notably during the Srivijaya and Majapahit periods. The latter, under Gajah Mada and King Hayam Wuruk, implemented a Mandala system with Majapahit at the center and surrounding kingdoms categorized as Mitra (friends/allies), ari (opponents/enemies), madhyama (middle power), and udasina (significant power).

section: Majapahit's Mandala System
text: Majapahit's Mandala system exemplified Kautilya's principles. Champa, rejecting Mongol hegemony, was considered a rear friend, embodying the “my enemy’s enemy is my friend” doctrine. Syangka, opposing the Chola kingdom, also became a Mitra. These alliances balanced the power of Majapahit's enemies. Ayudhya, a rising power in Central Indochina, was designated as Madhyama, while Ming Dynasty China, a major power, was Udasina. Majapahit pursued trade with China for regional stability but avoided political subordination.  The system differed from China's tributary system; kingdoms under Majapahit's protection retained autonomy. Diplomatic marriages further strengthened alliances.  This Mandala constellation mirrored the Mauryan system under Kautilya, reflecting the anarchic international order where alliances were crucial for protection and power preservation. While conquest (Vigraha) is often highlighted, Kautilya also advocated diplomacy: peace agreements (Samdhi), alliances (Samsraya), and neutrality (Asanas).  Majapahit prioritized cooperation, especially trade.

section: Mandala Theory in Modern Geopolitics and Indonesia's Defense
text: The Mandala concept persists in contemporary Indonesian foreign policy, although adapted to modern norms.  Concentric circles define cooperation priorities, with ASEAN as the innermost circle, followed by major powers and countries sharing common interests. This is reflected in ASEAN's regional architecture (ASEAN+1, +3, +6, East Asia Summit). Geopolitics, emphasizing the political significance of geography, and geostrategy, formulating national strategy based on geographical factors, are central to Indonesia's defense. Geopolitics recognizes land (continental) and sea (maritime) power streams; historically, the Maurya focused on land, while Srivijaya and Majapahit on sea. Frontier regions remain crucial for defense.  Indonesia, a maritime nation, prioritizes sea power, exemplified by its Global Maritime Fulcrum (GMF) policy in the Indo-Pacific.  This echoes the historical importance of sea routes for Srivijaya and Majapahit. The GMF responds to the geopolitical dynamics of the Indo-Pacific, where major powers (US, China, India, Japan, Australia) compete for influence. Indonesia's central position requires careful navigation, balancing relations with China for investment and infrastructure against concerns about regional stability and ASEAN unity.

section: Kautilya's Philosophy and Contemporary Relevance
text: Kautilya advocated for power acquisition and maintenance but emphasized societal welfare, morality, and unity.  His philosophy, though from a different era and context, shares common ground with Machiavelli's in emphasizing political morality and virtue. Indonesia, drawing upon ancient wisdom like Kautilya's, needs intelligence and unity, especially among its youth, to strengthen national defense. Kautilya's Mandala theory, adopted by ancient kingdoms like Ayudhya and Majapahit, now informs Indonesia's defense strategy, contributing to its position in Asia and globally. The modern implementation emphasizes concentric circles of cooperation, primarily within ASEAN.

section: Part 1: Historical Context and Key Principles
text: Chandragupta Maurya, guided by Chanakya (Kautilya), overthrew the Nanda Empire and consolidated control over a large portion of the Indian subcontinent. Chanakya authored the Arthashastra, a seminal work on statecraft and political economy, which includes the Mandal Theory.  This theory focuses on 'mandalas,' concentric circles representing levels of influence and power.  It emphasizes diplomacy, war, and territorial expansion to protect national interests and maintain a balance of power with neighboring states.  Modern geopolitical realism, developed by scholars like Hans Morgenthau and Kenneth Waltz, shares parallels with the Mandal Theory, particularly in their recognition of power and national interest as driving forces in international relations.

section: Part 2: Comparing Mandal Theory and Geopolitical Realism
text: Both the Mandal Theory and geopolitical realism prioritize power and security. Kautilya advocates for a strong military and defense.  Both theories also emphasize alliances and diplomacy to achieve national objectives. Territorial expansion is another shared aspect, viewed as a means to consolidate power and resources. However, both theories face criticism.  The focus on power and self-interest may neglect ethical considerations and cooperation. The Mandal Theory's emphasis on territorial expansion may clash with modern sovereignty principles. Despite these critiques, the Arthashastra remains relevant.  Scholars like R Zaman, L.K. Jha, K.K. Jha, Kavush Abosov, Roger Boesche, and R.P. Kangle have highlighted its historical significance and insights into political economy and statecraft. It is considered valuable for understanding ancient political thought and potentially informing contemporary diplomatic practices.

section: Part 3: Research on the Mandal Theory and Geopolitical Realism
text: This research aims to closely examine how Kautilya's Mandal Theory aligns with modern geopolitical realism.  The research questions explore the relationship between the two theories, their application to contemporary territorial disputes, and the influence of cultural, historical, and geographical factors on their interpretation.  The research methodology involves analyzing relevant verses from the Arthashastra, examining Kautilya's recommendations on diplomacy and foreign policy, and considering the historical context of ancient India. Secondary data from authoritative sources like R Shamasastry's and Udaiveer Shastri's translations of the Arthashastra, L.N. Rangarajan's commentary, and expert analyses will be used.  The research hypothesizes that the Mandal Theory is an early form of realism, a roadmap for diplomacy and foreign policy, and a reflection of ancient India's historical and cultural context.

section: Part 4: Analysis and Discussion of Hypotheses
text: The analysis uses original verses from the Arthashastra, cross-referenced with translations by L.N. Rangarajan and Udaiveer Shastri.  The first hypothesis, that the Mandal Theory is an early form of realism, is supported by shared tenets such as state-centrism, self-interest, balance of power, geopolitical considerations, and the acceptance of aggressive tactics when necessary.  Both theories prioritize the state's interests and recognize the importance of power dynamics. However, the Mandal Theory places greater emphasis on managing the immediate geopolitical environment (the mandala) than traditional realism. The second hypothesis, that the Mandal Theory is a roadmap for diplomacy and foreign policy, is explored through Kautilya's advice on neighborhood diplomacy, alliances, espionage, war (as a last resort), economic policy, assessment of neighboring states, and the use of deception and psychological warfare.

section: Introduction and Hypothesis
text:
Diplomacy and foreign policy in the Arthashastra reflects a realist perspective. It emphasizes the pursuit of self-interest and the use of a wide range of tools, including diplomacy, espionage, alliances, and military force, to protect and advance the state's interests in a competitive and anarchic international environment. His insights continue to be studied and have relevance in contemporary discussions of international relations and statecraft. Hypothesis 3: Ancient India's historical and cultural context is reflected in the Mandala Theory. The historical and cultural context of ancient India during Kautilya's time, commonly known as the Mauryan period (circa 4th to 3rd century BCE), had a significant impact on the development of Kautilya's Mandala Theory and his work, the Arthashastra. The following is a brief summary of the context:
1. Political Fragmentation: Before the rise of the Mauryan Empire, India was politically divided into a multitude of small kingdoms and republics. This political environment influenced Kautilya's understanding of statecraft and diplomacy, as he sought to establish a powerful, centralized state capable of consolidating power and managing relations with neighboring entities.
2. Social and Cultural Diversity: The cultural and religious diversity of ancient India was remarkable. Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, as well as numerous other religious and philosophical traditions, coexisted. This diversity contributed to a rich tapestry of ideas and values that shaped Kautilya's views on government and diplomacy.
3. Foreign Intrigues: It had interactions with neighboring states and empires, such as the Seleucid Empire and the Nanda Empire. These interactions exposed the Mauryans to the complexities of international relations and diplomacy, influencing Kautilya's views on how to navigate these international relations.
4. Political Philosophy: Ancient India provided a fertile intellectual environment for the development of political philosophy. The Arthashastra of Kautilya is regarded as one of the earliest works on statecraft and political science. It was influenced by the earlier writings of thinkers such as Manu and Brihaspati, as well as the contributions of contemporaries to the emerging field of political thought.
5. Economic and Trade Networks: Ancient India's extensive trade networks, which included the famous Silk Road, facilitated economic interactions with neighboring regions. Kautilya's political and foreign policy strategies were fundamentally influenced by the economic factors of trade and resource acquisition. Mandala Theory and the Arthashastra were profoundly influenced by the historical, political, cultural, and philosophical context of ancient India during Kautilya's time. His work demonstrates a pragmatic approach to statecraft and diplomacy, tailored to the complexities of the time and the ambitions of the Mauryan Empire.

section: Case Studies and Discussion
text:
There are real-world examples and case studies that demonstrate the application of the Mandala Theory and modern geopolitical realism in various historical and contemporary contexts. I will also provide a brief analysis of how these theories have influenced state policies, alliances, and conflicts in these instances.
1. Cold War Power Dynamics: During the Cold War, the Mandala Theory had a profound effect on the strategies of both superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union. They focused on their respective neighboring regions and endeavored to establish spheres of influence. The United States, for instance, implemented the Mandala Theory by forming alliances in its adjacent regions, such as NATO in Western Europe. Influence of Geopolitical Realism: Modern geopolitical realism is compatible with the bipolar power structure of the Cold War era. States vied for power and influence, with a concern for balance of power at the forefront. In superpower strategies, the realist approach of deterrence and containment was evident.
2. South China Sea Dispute: China's territorial claims and actions in the South China Sea can be analyzed using the Mandala Theory as a lens. China seeks to establish dominance in its immediate geopolitical environment and expand its sphere of influence, which frequently causes tensions with neighboring states like Vietnam, the Philippines, and Taiwan. Modern geopolitical realism can be used to comprehend the power balance dynamics in the South China Sea. Reflecting realist concerns about maintaining power balance, the United States and its allies have engaged in containment efforts to counter China's rise in the region.
3. Russian Annexation of Crimea and Ukraine War: The annexation of Crimea by Russia in 2014 is an illustration of the Mandala Theory in action. Russia viewed Crimea as a part of its immediate geopolitical sphere and sought to maintain its influence there, resulting in a conflict with Ukraine. Influence of Geopolitical Realism: The international response to Russia's actions reflects realist principles. Western nations imposed sanctions on Russia and supported Ukraine to counterbalance Russian expansion, demonstrating a realist commitment to maintaining power balance and safeguarding national interests. Now these sanctions resulted in Russia invading Ukraine.
4. India's Foreign Policy in South Asia: The Mandala Theory can be utilized to analyze India's foreign policy toward its South Asian neighbors. India seeks to maintain influence and form alliances in its neighboring regions, frequently engaging in diplomatic, economic, and military endeavors to protect its interests. Influence of Geopolitical Realism: India's realist approach aims to balance the power dynamics in South Asia, particularly in response to China's influence in the region. India's strategic alliances with Bhutan and Nepal reflect its realist concerns regarding the expansion of other regional powers. These cases demonstrate how the Mandala Theory and modern geopolitical realism can be applied to comprehend and analyze state policies, alliances, and conflicts in various historical and contemporary contexts. In today's complex geopolitical environment, these theories continue to be useful in the study of international relations and statecraft.

section: Conclusion and Recommendations
text:
Conclusion:
 The Mandala Theory, an early form of Realism in international relations, emphasizes the importance of the state and self-interest. It recognizes the anarchic nature of the international system and stresses the need for a balance of power in the state's immediate neighborhood (mandala) to prevent any single neighbor from becoming overly powerful and posing a threat.
 Realism, on the other hand, acknowledges the absence of a global government or authority, which leads to self-help and competition among states. The Mandala Theory stresses the significance of pursuing self-interest and national security as a state's primary objective, advocating for strategies that increase a state's power and prosperity. It also takes into account geographical and geopolitical factors when assessing the behavior of neighboring states, suggesting that geography can affect alliances and strategies.
 In the Arthashastra, Kautilya offers extensive counsel on diplomacy, foreign policy, and dealing with neighboring states. He emphasizes the significance of establishing and maintaining cordial relations with neighboring states, forming alliances and treaties, espionage and intelligence gathering, war as a last resort, economic and trade policy, deception and psychological warfare, assessment of neighboring states, maintenance of internal strength, balance of power, pragmatism and flexibility in foreign policy, and self-interest.

Recommendations:
 Encourage Further Comparative Research: Given the complexity and evolution of international relations, further comparative research exploring the overlaps and differences between Kautilya's Mandala Theory and modern geopolitical realism is important.
 Scholars should continue investigating how these theories apply to various regions and contexts, allowing for a deeper understanding of their implications for state conduct and alliances.
 Promote Cross-Cultural Dialogues: Cross-cultural dialogues between academics and policymakers can help bridge the gap between ancient Indian political thought and contemporary international relations. Encourage academic institutions and think tanks to organize conferences and seminars that bring together experts from diverse backgrounds to discuss the modern relevance of ancient theories.
 Diplomats and policymakers can benefit from understanding the insights provided by Kautilya's Mandala Theory and contemporary geopolitical realism. Promoting educational programs and training that acquaint practitioners with the historical and theoretical foundations of statecraft and diplomacy is crucial, allowing them to make more informed decisions within their roles.
 Analyze the Ethical Aspects: An examination of the ethical aspects of these theories should be encouraged. Academics and policymakers should investigate how applying Kautilya's Mandala Theory and contemporary geopolitical realism aligns with international norms, human rights, and ethical considerations. This can contribute to a more principled and ethical approach to state conduct and diplomacy.
 Raise Public Awareness: The significance of ancient political thought in the contemporary world should be brought to the public's attention. Educational institutions, the media, and government agencies can play a role in disseminating information about Kautilya's Arthashastra and other historical texts to improve public understanding of statecraft, diplomacy, and international relations.
